channel.title: Best New Albums - Pitchfork
channel.description: The best new releases from Pitchfork, the most trusted voice in music.

item.title: Popcaan: FIXTAPE
item.description: The dancehall superstar’s latest mixtape is the best of every facet of his work, from slow-wine ballads to summery head-bangers. It’s a testament to his place at the forefront of the genre.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Burney

item.title: The Microphones: Microphones in 2020
item.description: Phil Elverum resurrects his beloved Microphones alias for a 45-minute song about art-making, self-mythologizing, and the endless search for meaning.
item.dc:creator: Quinn Moreland

item.title: Dehd: Flower of Devotion
item.description: Recording in a studio, the Chicago DIY trio sound newly airy and lush, but no less direct and sincere. Their confidence in their concision is the best part.
item.dc:creator: Steven Arroyo

item.title: Julianna Barwick: Healing Is a Miracle
item.description: The vocalist and producer Juliana Barwick’s revelatory new album asks us to picture healing at a moment when the task feels impossible.
item.dc:creator: Will Gottsegen

item.title: Special Interest: The Passion Of
item.description: Mixing art-punk, industrial, and techno, the outstanding New Orleans four-piece emerge with a blistering vision of punk as possibility.
item.dc:creator: Jenn Pelly

item.title: Jessie Ware: What’s Your Pleasure?
item.description: On her disco-inspired new album, Ware sounds bolder, looser — and frankly, more fun — than she has in a near-decade.
item.dc:creator: Owen Myers

item.title: Haim: Women in Music Pt. III
item.description: The third album from the trio is far and away their best. Intimate, multidimensional, and wide-ranging, the songwriting shines with personality and a great curiosity for melody and style.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Cliff

item.title: Phoebe Bridgers: Punisher
item.description: On her marvelous second album, Phoebe Bridgers defines her songwriting: candid, multi-dimensional, slyly psychedelic, and full of heart. Her music has become a world unto itself.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sodomsky

item.title: Bob Dylan: Rough and Rowdy Ways
item.description: Six decades into his career, Bob Dylan delivers a gorgeous and meticulous record. It is the rare Dylan album that asks to be understood and comes down to meet its audience.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sodomsky

item.title: Drakeo the Ruler: Thank You For Using GTL
item.description: Recorded in jail over a crackly phone line, Drakeo’s mesmerizing album is a remarkable feat: a stark rebuke of the justice system and an unparalleled achievement for a rapper and his producer.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ismael Ruiz

item.title: Run the Jewels: RTJ4
item.description: On their fourth installment, Killer Mike and El-P are back to tune up the ruling class and the racist police state, this time streamlining the process and settling into their most natural rhythm.
item.dc:creator: Sheldon Pearce

item.title: Medhane: Cold Water
item.description: On his latest project, the Brooklyn rapper realizes his vision. His forceful and focused bars are just one aspect of the highly skilled emcee’s community-focused and spiritually rewarding music.
item.dc:creator: Sheldon Pearce

item.title: Perfume Genius: Set My Heart on Fire Immediately
item.description: Mike Hadreas’ fifth album glides between sublime melodies and grimy, guttural dissonance, embracing the joys and burdens of the human body and its innumerable, intangible yearnings.
item.dc:creator: Madison Bloom

item.title: Moses Sumney: græ
item.description: The sprawling second album from the crystal-voiced singer-songwriter is a riot of moods. Moses Sumney widens the scope of his work and takes full account of his self, warts and all.
item.dc:creator: Jayson Greene

item.title: Blake Mills: Mutable Set
item.description: On his fourth album, the expert producer comes into his own as a solo artist with a hushed, finely tuned album that showcases his unassuming voice and impeccable songcraft.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dombal

item.title: The Soft Pink Truth: Shall We Go On Sinning So That Grace May Increase?
item.description: Matmos member Drew Daniel has put together a gorgeous album that carries itself with the strength of a soft prayer, masterfully fusing jazz, deep house, and minimalism into an enormous, featherlight shield.
item.dc:creator: Miles Bowe

item.title: KeiyaA: Forever, Ya Girl
item.description: The Chicago-bred singer and producer’s homegrown R&B meditates on hurt, longing, and self-protection, embracing the kind of resolute realness that can only happen outside the major label gaze.
item.dc:creator: Claire Lobenfeld

item.title: Fiona Apple: Fetch the Bolt Cutters
item.description: Fiona Apple’s fifth record is unbound, a wild symphony of the everyday, an unyielding masterpiece. No music has ever sounded quite like it.
item.dc:creator: Jenn Pelly

item.title: Yves Tumor: Heaven to a Tortured Mind
item.description: The iconoclastic artist moves to a plush and magisterial kind of rock music for a gratifying and intense record, one whose pleasures are viscerally immediate.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Lozano

item.title: Waxahatchee: Saint Cloud
item.description: With a shift in tone and tempo, Katie Crutchfield creates a vivid modern classic of folk and Americana. It’s the sound of a cherished songwriter thawing out under the sun.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy D. Larson

item.title: Lyra Pramuk: Fountain
item.description: On her debut album, the American musician works entirely with recordings of her own voice, processing and layering largely non-verbal sounds to explore the very fiber of her being.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Saxelby

item.title: Jay Electronica: A Written Testimony
item.description: After years of waiting and mounting hype, Jay Electronica’s fantastic debut is a mystical, distinctive work that nearly lives up to all the lore surrounding the rapper.
item.dc:creator: Sheldon Pearce

item.title: Dogleg: Melee
item.description: The thrilling debut from the Detroit rock band burns hot and bright. It’s a record that’s as melodic as it is physical, where pent-up aggression turns into physical liberation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Cohen

item.title: Porridge Radio: Every Bad
item.description: The second album from the Brighton four-piece is the sound of a band mercilessly digging into itself with a stunning, dynamic performance from singer-songwriter Dana Margolin.
item.dc:creator: Jenn Pelly

item.title: Lil Uzi Vert: Eternal Atake
item.description: The Philly rapper has evolved into an untouchable pop artist in sound and style. With deliriously good rapping and immaculate production, Uzi makes an event album live up to its name.
item.dc:creator: Alphonse Pierre
